name: Christos Giannakopoulos
label: Physics Ph.D.
summary: Physics Ph.D. in experimental cosmology. Passionate about quantifying real-world problems and developing metrics to aid data-driven solutions. Thank you to Corey M. Schafer for the inspiration.

highlights: Project lead on instrumental systematic error studies in the BICEP/Keck Collaboration - an experimental cosmology team leading the field in measurements of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization.
Instrument calibration measurements, and analysis pipeline developement for the BICEP3 and BICEP Array CMB polarimeters located at the South Pole.

Quantified the impact of systematic errors to the science goal of measuring the tensor-to-scalar ratio 'r'. A non-zero measurement of r, would constitute proof of Inflation and primordial gravitational waves.
Designed an LLM model that uses Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) to provide collaboration-specific answers to technical questions regarding the BICEP3 and BICEP Array experiments.
Multi-component maximum likelihood analysis
Time-ordered CMB data simulation and analysis using advanced mathematical methods, such as generalized convolutions on the sphere, without relying on manifold connection information.
Ground temperature stability analysis at the South Pole using BICEP Array data.
Taught and coordinated physics labs and recitations for 200+ students.
Utilized active learning techniques to stimulate student engagement to maximize learning outcomes.
Bolstered learning of complex physics concepts through problem-solving sessions.
Taught and tutored undergraduates on the fundementals of Physics
Characterized Pulsar Wind Nebulae phenomenology using data from the Sardinia Radio Telescope (SRT)

projects.preamble: This section contains a small list of projects I develop while pursuing my Physics Ph.D., and are relevant to my interests and hobbies. These include both applied and more theoretical topics and I update them from time-to-time. Some of these projects are notes on existing mathematical tools or notions that I add my personal insight to. Note: this list of projects is exclusively side-projects and do not include any analysis of real Cosmological data.
projects.title: Machine Learning Specialization & Deep Learning
projects.summary: I have recently completed the Machine Learning Learning Specialization by Andrew Ng of the Stanford AI Lab. With the rise of Machine Learning tools and applications, understanding the mathematical formalism behind these tools is crucial for any data-driven field. Especially when selecting the right tool to solve a specific problem.
highlights: Supervised Learning Algorithms, Unsupervised Learning Algorithms, and Deep Learning Fundamentals.
Decision Trees, Random Forests, and Convolutional Neural Networks
Reinforcement Learning, Transfer Learning
Model Validation, Hyperparameter Tuning, Deep Learning Architectures
TensorFlow, Keras, PyTorch.

projects.title: Financial Modeling - Compound Interest Calculator
projects.summary: Outside of my research in Physics, I am passionate about understanding and modeling financial markets. Most recently, I built my own compound interest calculator from first principles. I noticed that a lot of the calculator online lack tranparency in their calculations and can be perceived as fairly limited to a financially educated person. This custom-built calculator is meant to be used by such person. Since this project's completion, I have been exploring the impact of home-building on the broader housing market using a Bayesian Statistics approach. Stay tuned for more updates on that!
highlights: Custom and Interactive Compound Interest Calculator in Python.
All-in-one adjustable options for retirement forecasting.
Packaged in a pedagogical manner with full methodology breakdown
Built with Streamlit for easy web deployment - no backend.
Open-source code on GitHub, Click the title to check it out!

projects.title: Model Parameter Estimation with Maximum Likelihood
projects.summary: I am passionate about statistics. Maximum likelihood estimation is a branch of statistics that is sometimes poorly motivated when taught in higher education. This project is an attempt at showing all the mathematical steps that lead to the maximum likelihood estimation method
highlights: Worked example of how maximum likelihood approach is used when estimating model parameters
Full formalism behind the worked example, explained step-by-step

projects.title: Simulation of Cosmic Microwave Background Signals
projects.summary: You might wonder what the signal from the first light of our Universe looks like when measure by the most sensitive detectors on the planet. In this project I explore exactly that! I simulate the universe at that time using existing cosmic microwave background (CMB) simulation packages in Python, and sample it with detectors
highlights: Simulate time-ordered data from a single realization of the temperature and polarization signal of our Universe 380,000 years after its birth
Realistic noise simulation
Using realistic curved sjy projection

images.caption: Time-ordered data of CMB signal and noise

projects.title: Notes on Mutlivariate Linear Regression
projects.summary: One of the biggest challenges in an analytical field is converting a real-world problem into a mathematical one. This can be achieved with a mathematical parametric model. To extract information about the model one can use the process of linear regression. It is especially relevant in the field of statistics, machine learning, etc. The aim of this project is to illustrate the power of linear regression
highlights: Linear regression for pedestrians
With some linear algebra, get a powerful estimating tool

projects.title: New York Times `Wordle` Game in Python
projects.summary: Ever played the popular NYT Wordle? Every day there is a secret five-letter word need to guess in only 6 tries! I coded the game in Python for fun! Needs a bit of work to make the UI more appealing.
highlights: - Fun Python Game -

publications.title: Calibration Measurements of the BICEP3 and BICEP Array CMB Polarimeters from 2017 to 2024
publications.author: Primary
publications.summary: This paper presents an overview of calibration measurements of the BICEP3 and BICEP Array polarimeters at the South Pole that enhances our understanding of instrument performance and systematic errors. It was presented as part of the International Society of Optics and Photonics (SPIE) Conference in June 2024 in Yokohama, Japan. The results are relevant for the ongoing efforts to measure excess B-mode polarization of the CMB.

publications.title: Pulsar scintillation through thick and thin: Bow shocks, bubbles, and the broader interstellar medium
publications.author: Secondary
publications.summary: Excellent paper on Pulsar scintillation by Stella Koch Ocker. Relevant to my undergraduate research using data I helped take during the summer of 2018.
